You should look to the future.  Envision what you want out of your career. Picture in your mind, if everything was to go perfectly, where you’d want to end up - and what you’d want to end up doing. Take that as your final goal, and work back from it. Outline what you could achieve in the next 5 years to get yourself closer to that goal. Would you need certain qualifications that you can start working towards? Would you need experience in other areas that you can start looking for? Or would you want a complete career change? Is there anything you can start doing now to prepare for your transition into the career you really want?  If you want to improve something, you need a motivation. In order to create reliable motivation, you need a concrete plan of how you’re going to achieve your goals. Setting and achieving goals is how improvement is done.  For an easy to follow method of planning and achieving your goals, see this answer.

Become a ‘scholar’ of your profession. If you are in sales or business development for example, study every aspect of selling and marketing. I mean the basics. Then advanced. Then go practice what you read or learned in the real world. Keep finding new ways to practice your craft. Make your approach unique, ‘branded’ to you. See where your next steps could be. Never stop learning about how your strengths can be used in new ways. Then take a risk and study another part of your company that makes you more valuable. Finally, if your position can be a source of direct income to the company, you’re ‘a leg up’ on people in staff positions. They are overhead. Just my experience. Good Luck! Ben

If you’re thinking about going to college, you can get ahead by enrolling in a technical school instead of the traditional 4-year degree. Because trade school traditionally takes about two years to complete, vocational trainees can get into the workforce earlier — in about half the time as someone who attends a traditional four-year college. This allows workers to get an additional two years of income over a four-year college graduate. What’s even better is that blue-collar workers have the potential to earn the same salary as a white-collar worker, and maybe even out earn their white-collar peers down the line!

The first thing is to do the best you can at your current job. Go above and beyond to exceed your goals. The second is that you need to be the go-to person for your team when your manager is unavailable. The third is helping other groups outside your own. This way you’re building your profile as a leader within and outside of your team. If you do these three things, you are basically doing the role of the next level up in your career, and you will be a shoo-in for the position when it comes up. Also, advocate for yourself. Let multiple levels of your leadership know that you’re here to prove yourself and that you want to grow your career. I am continually impressed when top performers approach me early on to discuss their ambitions and then follow through.

Original question: what are you doing to advance in your profession Reading to expand my scientific knowledge. I have more than enough knowledge to teach my high school biology classes as it stands. I could just review my notes before class, reread my textbooks to refresh my memory and teach the class. But I would not be the best possible teacher I could be if I didn’t keep on expanding my scientific content knowledge. So last year I read On the Origin of Species. I have taught evolutionary biology for a decade but I never read the entirety of Darwin’s seminal work. I didn’t “need” to read it all (and I breezed through some of the slower chapters) - I know enough to teach what is a relatively surface level of evolutionary biology. But to understand just how much effort Darwin put in to developing evidence gave me significant insight into just how amazing his theory was and continues to be. It informs my teaching and expands my enthusiasm for continued teaching. It allows me to continue to be excited for teaching the same topic every year; knowing that I “know” my topic better and have greater command of the facts and that my expertise and ability to convey the material is stronger makes this the best job I could imagine.

The best way to do better in your career, is by listening to feedback and asking what you can do better. If you are already working somewhere show them that you are willing to learn more and that you are ready to handle more responsibility. If you don’t have work yet and you just want to boost your career, you need to market yourself better. Show companies your great skills and don’t be afraid. The thing that companies really like is ‘why’ you want to work and what your goal is in life. They also want to know where you want to be in the next couple of years. Really start learning more about who you are.

Make sure it is what you truly want to do in your life. If you love what you are doing you will never work a day in your life. Start as early as you can to take classes toward your career. Don't worry if you are not noticed in the beginning. You will be. Just do the best job you can. Don't perform only when observed. Perform all the time, because you never know when you will be observed. Make yourself indispensable by learning the jobs of others and being the best at your job. If you get called on your day off to come in, that means you have achieved that. Remember, knowledge is power. Share it wisely. Lest the person you teach may replace you. Impart the knowledge to someone worthy when you are ready to retire.

There can be a number of things that you will have to learn in order to enhance your career. Nobody can define the set of rules or things that you need to have for giving your career a new height. More or less, it is a combination of various factors and things that you put together. I feel that you should learn to be focused towards finding solutions rather than sticking to problems. Problems are going to be there every time and there will be many who will highlight the problem, but only a few manage to come up with solutions. This is something that you should aim at.

Find something you are good at and enjoy doing. Stick to your guns no matter what people tell you. Life can be tough, but it’s much tougher if you give up on your own dreams and become a sheep! You may have to do some crappy jobs if you’re following your dreams. But it’s better to have a long term plan and keep your eye on a bigger prize which most people don’t see. If you’ve got your eye on a large goal, there’s nothing you can’t do in the interim to get though. If you feel like you’ve settled, your goal isn’t big enough! There will be times when everyone seems to see things differently than you do. Learn to trust your own path under difficult circumstances and keep going no matter what. Following the herd seldom is a successful strategy for happiness, peace and satisfaction.

80% - Focus on mastering tasks, and build relationships with anybody who has any part in the product/service you provide. 20% - As you get the 80% in hand (3–9 months), be on the lookout for a major project that will cut costs or increase revenue. Then, persistently work on it and make it happen. Don’t ask permission, and don’t be obvious about what you are doing. And don’t let anybody discourage you from your project. Companies are about making money, and they advance people who make them money.

I am assuming you chose work you are interested in and your choice wasn't solely based on potential earnings. I'm also assuming you know your area of expertise well. Keep it nicely polished. Keep your ears open and mouth reasonably zipped, especially when you start a new job. Think before you act. Sleep on the issue for a night.  People skills are extremely under-rated. Show you are genuinely interested in your colleagues as people rather than cogs. You may not become a CEO because they tend to have the killer instinct but it will get you far. If you look after a team, figure out what each person's motivation is. It varies widely. Look after your people and they will look after you. It's a delicate balance. If you are too 'nice' it will not work. If you get it right, success is guaranteed. Good luck with it.

I love Daryl's #1 answer - Commit to Exploratory Work!  The percentage of young adults who actually explore is so low, that when you do so and demonstrate passionate curiosity, respect and appreciation towards Guides, you'll stand out. Guides are loose tie connections who really want to help Explorers. The Explorer simply asks for some of the Guide's time. She's not looking for the end all Mentor, she's just looking for knowledge, information and wisdom. Following that initial conversation she asks the Guide if it'd be all right to touch base in the future and if they'd be interested in her progress.  Btw, the second most important thing an Explorer does following a visit with a Guide is to send a hand written thank you note. The first? Well it's a combination. Heart-fully thank the Guide in person and ask if they know of anyone else who would be willing to spend a twenty minutes in a similar conversation.

I’ll share a secret( don’t tell anyone). Your mentor probably can’t help you “climb the corporate ladder”. Everyone seems to have mentors thinking that’s the solution. It’s not! A mentor can offer advice, but incase you’re wondering how those suckers at your job ascend to higher heights and nothing you do seems to work there is a whole new term for that: A sponsor! Someone at a level high enough to pull strings for you and make things happen. A mentor helps you get a job. A sponsor creates the job. Never confuse a mentor with a sponsor! Which one do you have? Always start with making it very clear what you mean by improving your career. If you very clearly name what it is that you want to accomplish and how you want things to be, then you will know what is an improvement or not. For some people that really want to be doing a certain type of work, so they are going to transition from one kind of work to another, they may take a pay hit. It may not be clear that that could be progress if it will get you to where you want to go. So step back and really look at the whole picture and when you name that, you will be able to see how you are doing so much better.

There is a lot of great answers here. I’ll add/emphasize just a few things: Make your intentions clear. Tell your leaders where you want to go in your career and solicit feedback on what you can do to improve. Listen carefully and keep this dialogue open. Many employees do not do this, and it’s one of the most effective ways of letting them know that you want to learn and grow.Find a sponsor/mentor. Someone who will look out for you - build a genuine relationship with that person. Organizations are political - helps when you have someone on your side rooting for you.Leverage your strengths. Nobody is perfect. Find your strength and ways to contribute to the organizarion most effectively with your strengths.

By setting a goal, finding out what you like to do and then doing everything possible to absolutely work towards doing what you love to do.  Note, this does not mean abandoning your current job or a lucrative job to find your "life work".  Too many people don't understand that you can have two jobs in your life..the one  you work, and the one you work to be able to work. (ie. Lawyer to bread maker);  Or in my case, business financier, accountant, then teacher.

The simple 5 step formula: 1. Make a plan2. Generate resources for the plan3. Make efforts to achieve the goal4. Execute the plan.5. Cherish and respect what you get. Backup: This is the most important part of planning. Always have a plan B.There are times when you may not achieve what you aspire or worse case, you may loose what you get. Or even worse, you may have a self realisation that what you got. Was not exactly what you wanted. And that is when your plan B comes to the rescue. The next thing to remember is, even if you do not get anything (which is rare,but there) do not loose hope. Hope is the biggest virtue. Till the day you have hope, you can never loose. Work hard. Have fun. P.S- The secret-  always have a Plan C for your Plan B. Cheers..!/

Well it depends on which stage of your career you are. Assuming that it the start of your career. Lets start by sharing with you this answer about things you need to know when starting your career. Someone anonymous's answer to What career advice do you have for recent graduates? Secondly, there are so many things when questions you need to ask yourself like. What career path do I need to select? (Million dollar question) as it determines everything else that follows up.Will my career give me happiness, money and work life balance. My best piece of advice for career development is, don't waste time and start as early as possible. Ususally young people are very confused with what they want to do in life and keep wasting time in searching for their passion or in discovering their calling. The best way to know your passion is to do what you get in a best possible way. With time, you will discover your calling. The best advantage of this thing is that, the early you start, more the time you have to discover your passion. This is the best way for a good career development.

Look for opportunities. Take advantage of any chance to gain some added knowledge. Maybe you can take a special program during the summer months. Perhaps your college offers a January term, when you can take a course in a subject that interests you. You may be able to use that experience later. I got into a PhD program by presenting a lecture on studies I had learned about when taking a summer program at Los Alamos.

Have an end goal. Do you remember being asked 'what do you want to be when you grow up?'  What did you say?  Is that answer still true today?  If not, do you know why?  To create a fulfilling career that's the first step, understanding your career goal. After that, you just begin to move towards it.  Getting the experience, qualifications and contacts that will help you to achieve your goal. I know, I've made it sound simple and it's not.  But that's where you start - by being clear about your goal. ------------------------------------------- Thanks for the A2A.  If you've found the answer useful please remember to upvote.  Also, why not follow my blog Fulfilling Careers there's a post there with your name on it.  Best wishes.

Well, each career is different in terms of what skills are essential. And it’s not realistic to present all of the skills required for success in any career. saying NO. the project damager comes by asking for some changes due on Monday. he has a list of requirements. all of which need to be made from zero or modified from the existing. doing this will take the weekend. instead of saying, “yeah sure…” to be a team player, push back, find out what is really being asked and why. it may be that no changes are actually required. it may be that the changes really have to get done and the PD is all in with you. but you would not know that unless you took a stand for NO. now, repeat after me… just say NO.
